title: 106_s226
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Nigerian Democracy and Civil Society Empowerment Act of 1999". It includes findings and a declaration of policy. The Act "Nigerian Democracy and Civil Society Empowerment Act of 1999" highlights Congress's findings on the negative impact of successive military regimes in Nigeria, praising the progress made by the current regime under Gen. Abdusalami Abubakar towards political liberalization. The current government in Nigeria has cooperated with the United States to combat drug trafficking and criminal organizations. Limited sanctions were imposed by the international community in response to human rights violations and political repression, some of which have been lifted due to recent political liberalization. However, certain decrees still suspend constitutional protections of human rights, allow indefinite detention without charge, and limit civilian court jurisdiction over executive actions. Nigeria is obligated to conduct fair elections and has played a major role in peacekeeping efforts in Liberia and Sierra Leone. Despite progress, challenges remain in the country. Despite progress in Nigeria, recent events in the Niger Delta highlight the need for ongoing monitoring to prevent a return to repressive methods by the military. The United States aims to support democratic transition in Nigeria through political, economic, and legal reforms to ensure rule of law and respect for human rights. The Sense of Congress is stated in Section 3. The Sense of Congress in Section 3 emphasizes the importance of international cooperation in promoting the rule of law, respect for human rights, and the transition to democratic civilian government. It also calls for the condemnation of human rights abuses in Nigeria at the United Nations Human Rights Commission meeting. The Sense of Congress emphasizes international cooperation for promoting the rule of law, human rights, and democratic transition. It calls for condemning human rights abuses in Nigeria at the UN Human Rights Commission and pressing for the renewal of the special rapporteur's mandate. Assistance to promote democracy and civil society in Nigeria is emphasized. Assistance to promote democracy, good governance, and the rule of law in Nigeria through nongovernmental organizations is allocated specific funding amounts for fiscal years 2000, 2001, and 2002 under the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961. The Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 allocates funding to promote democracy, good governance, and the rule of law in Nigeria through nongovernmental organizations. The Administrator of the United States Agency for International Development ensures that recipients represent a broad cross-section of society and aim to promote human rights and accountable government. Grants are provided to support individuals or organizations. The Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 allocates funding to promote democracy, good governance, and the rule of law in Nigeria through grants of up to $25,000 for individuals or NGOs. A portion of the funding is designated for the United States Information Agency to support activities in Nigeria, including promoting awareness of constitutional democracy and human rights. Congress also acknowledges the need to assess staff levels at the United States Agency for International Development office in Nigeria. Congress finds that staff levels at the USAID office in Lagos, Nigeria are inadequate and recommends increasing personnel to carry out necessary tasks. Prohibition on economic and military assistance to Nigeria, as well as opposition to multilateral assistance for Nigeria. Prohibition on economic assistance to the Government of Nigeria, including funds previously appropriated for economic assistance. Economic assistance defined as assistance under the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 and financing by the Export-Import Bank of the United States. Prohibition on military assistance or arms transfers to Nigeria, including funds previously appropriated for such purposes. Military assistance or arms transfers defined as assistance under chapter 2 of part II of relevant legislation. The term "military assistance or arms transfers" includes assistance under relevant legislation such as the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 and the Arms Export Control Act. The Arms Export Control Act authorizes the transfer of defense articles and services. The Secretary of the Treasury must oppose any assistance to the Government of Nigeria from international financial institutions. The Arms Export Control Act authorizes the transfer of defense articles and services. The Secretary of the Treasury must oppose any assistance to the Government of Nigeria from international financial institutions such as the African Development Bank, International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, International Development Association, International Finance Corporation, Multilateral Investment Guaranty Agency, and International Monetary Fund. The Arms Export Control Act authorizes the transfer of defense articles and services. Congress urges the denial of visas to senior Nigerian government officials and military officers unless a democratic transition occurs. Waiver of prohibitions against Nigeria is possible if specific requirements are met. The President can waive prohibitions in sections 5 or 6 for a fiscal year if a determination is made regarding Nigeria's human rights practices and a notification is sent to Congress. The determination includes criteria such as respecting freedom of speech and releasing imprisoned individuals. The President can waive prohibitions in sections 5 or 6 for a fiscal year if a determination is made regarding Nigeria's human rights practices, including releasing imprisoned individuals and respecting freedom of speech. Nigeria must also meet criteria such as providing access for international human rights monitors and repealing laws that grant undue powers to the military or allow indefinite detention without charge. The President can waive prohibitions in sections 5 or 6 for a fiscal year if a determination is made regarding Nigeria's human rights practices. Special tribunals must respect due process, and policing in oil-producing communities should not involve excessive force or human rights violations against civilians. Congressional notification is required 15 days in advance of any waiver. The President can waive prohibitions in sections 5 or 6 for a fiscal year with a determination on Nigeria's human rights practices, subject to reprogramming notification procedures under the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961. SEC. 8. REPORT OF CORRUPTION IN NIGERIA.

Within 3 months of this Act's enactment, and annually for the next 5 years, the Secretary of State must submit a report on corruption in Nigeria to congressional committees and the public. The report will cover evidence of corruption by Nigerian government officials, its impact on government services, US business interests, fraudulent schemes affecting US citizens, and Nigeria's foreign policy.

SEC. 9. APPROPRIATE CONGRESSIONAL COMMITTEES DEFINED. SEC. 9. APPROPRIATE CONGRESSIONAL COMMITTEES DEFINED. The term "appropriate congressional committees" refers to specific committees in the House of Representatives and the Senate. SEC. 10. TERMINATION DATE. The provisions of this Act will end on September 30, 2004.
